identificationModule.briefTitle: Role of Body Composition in Large for Gestational Age Infants (LGA) With Oral Feeding Difficulty
identificationModule.officialTitle: Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial Comparing FFM-indexed Feeding vs. Standard Feeding in LGA Infants With Oral Feeding Difficulty and Disproportionate Body Composition.

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Large for Gestational Age (LGA) infants have excess fat-mass (FM) proportion secondary to prolonged in utero exposure to an energy-rich environment. Our preliminary data suggest that excess FM proportion can be associated with oral feeding delay and a potentially modifiable therapeutic target to improve oral feeding outcomes. The objective of this study is to determine the impact of a short-term Fat-free mass (FFM)-indexed feeding on the oral intake volumes in LGA infants with oral feeding difficulties.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Eligible subjects will be randomized to an innovative FFM-indexed feeding or the standard feeding for up to 2 weeks. The essential component of the FFM-indexed feeding will be the difference in milk prescription dosing that we propose to set the feeding volume to index FFM rather than total mass. In FFM-indexed feeding, there will be a permissive feeding volume restriction to 150 ± 10 mL/kg (FFM)/day without increasing the milk calorie density or changing the type of formula milk, whereas the standard feeding will include a feeding volume goal of 150 ± 10 mL/kg (body weight)/day. Infants will receive either breast milk or formula feedings per the standard feeding protocols. Body composition (PEAPOD system) and appetite-regulating hormones (ARH) levels of enrolled infants will be assessed at baseline (test-1) and at the end 2-week study intervention period (test-2). Subjects will be followed for clinical and growth outcomes until neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) discharge and through 6 months of age. Growth will be followed through 6 months of age by retrieving anthropometric measurement records from pediatricians at well-child visits (2-, 4-, 6- and 6-month visits). Parents will be called at these time points to obtain a history of any further feeding difficulties.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The sample size for this pilot study will be 40 with 20 infants randomized into each arm.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: The data analyzer will be masked to the allocation

armGroups.label: FFM-indexed feeding
armGroups.description: In FFM-indexed feeding, there will be a permissive feeding volume restriction to 150 ± 10 mL/kg (FFM)/day without increasing the milk calorie density or changing the type of formula milk for 2 weeks in the intervention group

armGroups.label: Standard feeding
armGroups.description: The standard feeding approach will include an oral feeding volume goal of 150 ± 10 mL/kg/day during the 2-week study period

interventions.name: Dietary intervention
interventions.description: energy-restricted diet appropriate for resting metabolic rate using FFM as proxy

primaryOutcomes.measure: Time from study entry to independent oral feeding
primaryOutcomes.description: full oral feeding defined as 120 ml/kg/d without tube feeding for 2 consecutive days

secondaryOutcomes.measure: oral feeding volume at NICU discharge
NICU Feeding related length of stay (LOS)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Days from first oral feeding to independent oral feeding
Percentage of infants with gastrostomy placement
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: through study completion, an average of 1 year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Directional changes in ARH pre-post intervention
Independent oral feeding at NICU discharge

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Body composition change in FM and FFM
secondaryOutcomes.description: Directional changes in FM and FFM pre-post intervention

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* LGA infants with oral feeding difficulty born at ≥ 35 weeks gestation, with FM z-score \> +1.0 in body composition measurement

Exclusion Criteria:

* Infants on any respiratory support, Infants on enteral feeding duration \> 60 minutes due to hypoglycemia concerns, videofluoroscopic swallow study (VFSS) demonstrating unsafe swallowing function, GI surgical conditions, significant neurological morbidities, and major congenital, genetic syndromes/anomalies

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: Data requests can be submitted starting 9 months after article publication and the data will be made accessible for up to 24 months. Extensions will be considered on a case-by-case basis
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Data requests can be submitted starting 9 months after article publication
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: Access to trial IPD can be requested by qualified researchers engaging in independent scientific research, and will be provided following review and approval of a research proposal and Statistical Analysis Plan (SAP) and execution of a Data Sharing Agreement (DSA)
